Once begun, it was a novel that had to win me over and earn my trust, in large part, perhaps, because I was skeptical of a young Western writer, not so far removed from his Iowa Writers’ Workshop residency, with no direct connection to the region and its warring ethnicities and sides, venturing into such traumatic terrain. But win me over Marra and Constellation did, eventually even reminding me, in some respects, of a more prose-dense and contemporary version of Ondaatje’s The English Patient. The novel takes time to gather momentum and force, and maybe, as it slides back and forth from chapter-to-chapter to years in the 1994-2004 period, it tries too hard to formalize the disjointed, broken sense of time that ensues from trauma and nearly a post-apocalyptic experience. Marra’s research, one senses, is deeply and conscientiously realized, and in such a way that it never (or rarely) seems to be “worn on its sleeve.” What eventually transfixed me were the evocations of the haunted, wintry, and forlorn landscape, and especially the indelible characters, those spectral individuals still seeking beauty, love, and life wherever (and however partially) they can. At its best, there is a hallucinatory power to this novel, marked by poetic and powerful images of the realities of war: at one point, we learn that Havaa’s parents, “among other villagers, pried toilet bowls from the rubble of collapsed houses and dragging them upside down and two by two gently set them over the unexploded shells.” And dear Havaa is surely guaranteed to linger in the reader's consciousness. Nor should any of us turn away from it. Montaigne, after all, believed that it was a good thing to spend at least some small part of each day thinking about death; “let us deprive death of its strangeness,” he tells us, “let us frequent it, let us get used to it.” Montaigne’s urgings are all the more important given the dearth of mourning rituals in the West, a fact that O’Rourke bemoans in her book. Anguished, candid, brave, poetic, smart and scholarly, O’Rourke’s meditations are as universal as they are intensely personal. I learned a great deal from this book and, despite its subject matter, I found myself unable to put it down; it’s the kind of intellectual and emotional experience I wanted and expected from the more celebrated memoirs of loss that have appeared in recent years (I think, for example, of Joan Didion's pair of books). O’Rourke not only provides a spirited and tender tribute to her mother, but she also reflects deeply and movingly on love and loss, on family, on life’s transience and frailties, and on the otherworldliness of grief. She recognizes sorrow as not so much a state as a process; the painful but necessary growth into a new person that the bereaved must enact after a great loss is to be understood, she explains, as “not an emergence from the cocoon, but a tree growing around an obstruction.” And what greater obstruction than one’s “unmothering” – that irreplaceable portal closing, that line of knowledge fading? It’s a novel that alternates between the spirit of Wordsworth’s “Immortality Ode,” with all of its boyish kineticism (“Ran across a field of daisies at warp speed but keep your eyes on the ground. It’s ace. Petaled stars and dandelion comets streak the green universe. (Fans of indie music, by the way, may want to consider Okkervil River’s brilliant “The Silver Gymnasium” (2013) as the ideal companion text and soundtrack for this novel)Anchoring it all is the endearing, funny, and keenly observant Jason Taylor, a “middle-ranking” kid in the social hierarchy, a seeker in the suburbs, an aspiring poet with a stammer. The novel details thirteen months in the life of the thirteen year-old Jason, and although it’s Mitchell’s most conventional and least pyrotechnical novel it gives the impression of being both highly controlled and completely random at the same time. Each chapter reads as a kind of short story, at one time emphasizing domestic unease and fighting parents (whose “arguments’re speed chess these days”) and at another time, in the Bridle Path episode, for example, detailing an adventure story that could be a miniature Fellowship of the Ring narrative. Whether the kids are in the suburban driveways or the mysterious Malvern Hills, it’s always an enchanted geography, an enchantment that’s half found and half created by the youthful imagination.Joining Jason are a memorably diverse group of friends and antagonists who create a kind of Dickensian density to the social universe of the village of Black Swan Green. A sampling from the roll call of names tells a story of its own (and likely carries any reader back to the characters of his or her own grade school years): Ross Wilcox, Squelch, Pete Redmarley, Ant Little, Darren Croome, Grant Burch, et al. The novel evokes youthful elation and rites of passage (trying cigarettes for the first time, fighting war games in the woods, going “nightcreeping” through the village, etc.), the difficult negotiations of one’s place in the social scale, the attempts to neutralize the threats of bullies (“Stupidly, I tried to downgrade his attack by smiling”), who can make our protagonist feel as if “Planet Earth’d shrunk to a bubble five paces wide.” Speaking of shrinking, part of this novel’s power and resonance is its poignant depiction of a world and a state of being that inevitably close behind us, like the battlefields and playgrounds of Jason and his friends, whose “ways in’ve been wired off or walled up by brambles and farmers.” All in all, it's ace....more

Dell’s voice is world-weary and suffused with quiet heartbreak (which is accentuated by the lonely prairie towns of northern Montana and Canada in which the action, such as it is, unfolds); when he is taken to Partreau, Canada, following the incarceration of his parents and the separation from his sister, Dell observes “I was now smaller in the world’s view and insignificant, and possibly invisible. My Bright Abyss finds him mediating -- with a poet's sensibility, of course -- the often unbridgeable divide between secular and religious approaches to life; Wiman recognizes himself as someone with both an "honest modern consciousness" and an impulse for some manner of active devotion. And the stakes are high: during his recent battle with a rare cancer, Wiman knows what it's like "when death leans over to sniff you, when massive unmetaphorical pain goes crawling through your bones, when fear ... ices your bones." Suspecting "faith's latency" in adult years that he had assumed were simply faithless, and seeking an awareness that's true to his intimations of the "transcendent nature of grace," Wiman craves "the poetry and the prose of knowing." As a poet, though, he's especially suspicious of organized religion and dogma, and doesn't trust "the ropes, clips, and toe spikes whereby one descends into the abyss"; he needs and he seeks equipment that's less "worn and inadequate," so that he can feel he's doing more than "wandering through a discount shopping mall of myth, trying to convince [himself] there's something worth buying." The speaker's "representative," we infer, is a modern-day seeker, one for whom "the ghostly silt" of Christ may have dispersed, but who still hungers for a rediscovered faith and spirituality. review: Great art is so often (and perhaps so inevitably) born out of suffering and sorrow, and we look to artists to transmute such pain into something that Great art is so often (and perhaps so inevitably) born out of suffering and sorrow, and we look to artists to transmute such pain into something that affirms and consoles. Having lost a dear companion of my own recently, I appreciate Goldman's 340-page reminder that our response to loss is maybe first and foremost to eulogize, to narrativize, to preserve in words so as somehow to ward off the loss of detail and the weakening of memory. We want not only to keep our loved ones alive, but also somehow to find a way to make the world know how wonderful that partner, that friend, even that dog, really was. Say Her Name is a flawed, messy, undisciplined book in some respects, but one doesn’t hold it against Goldman because he’s being true to his feelings and to his lost love, Aura Estrada, more than to the dictates of narrative shape. He unceasingly finds himself “descending into memory like Orpheus to bring Aura out alive for a moment,” knowing that these “futile little rites and reenactments” bring both temporary comfort and renewed pain; one thinks of Tennyson’s famous lines from In Memoriam A.H.H., when he wills himself into believing, “I hold it true, whate’er befall; / I feel it, when I sorrow most; / ‘Tis better to have loved and lost / Than never to have loved at all.” Say Her Name is a literary “quivering” (the old practice of recalling the lives of those who have recently departed), an unspooling of a life so as to replay it, all the while balancing the absurd hope that it might somehow end differently with the knowledge that of course it can’t. Aura is vibrant and alive in these pages, and as the book’s concluding moments approach, the reader finds it hard to believe that she can actually die. The account of the accident itself is harrowing and heartrending, but somehow it’s overcome by the bright comet that was her life, and by the residual light of her after-shine. Even if every day is a “ghostly ruin” for Goldman, “every day the ruin of the day that was supposed to have been,” he (and we) are lifted up by “the memory-sensation of Aura laughing inside [him],” arriving unexpectedly, “as if crossing over from the spirit world.” Goldman knows, finally, that he can only “say her name. Graham Joyce’s The Silent Land is not as stylistically refined and elevated as these other titles, and the dialogue often doesn’t seem to rise to the level of what the protagonists are experiencing, but it’s the type of novel that almost can’t fail to produce a memorable reading experience (which will itself, by the way, considering you’ll be reluctant to put the book down after you’ve read the first five pages, be quite fleeting); further, despite at times suggesting a cross between the films Ghost and The Shining, it ultimately manages to be more profound than it has any right being. It’s hard to know how to write about this novel without giving something crucial away, but in important respects it’s about continuity and the mysterious apprehension of time; it’s about how a strong love can, in the words of the male protagonist, Jake, cheat death by creating “extra time” (to use a sports analogy, the plot operates in something like the equivalent of “45’ + 5”—or “stoppage time”—in a soccer game.) The mystery at the heart of this novel is that it may finally be a story involving twenty minutes, or involving a number of days or months or years, or even involving endless time. It’s a story about time and memory and love and loss, but it’s also about mountains and snow and alpine lodges and burning logs and sex and skiing and candles and the taste of cognac. It’s a tactile novel, a sonic novel (with sounds both big and small), and an eerily-lit novel, as ominously transfixing as those “spruce and pines, all still loaded with snow, [spreading] their limbs in a frozen ballet, breathing a ghostly incense from dark, arid chapels sheltered by their branches.” For anyone who has mourned a pet, the reunion of Jake and his dog Sadie will be a poignant one, and the narrative also pauses for a pair of moonlit and graceful remembrances of Zoe’s and Jake’s respective fathers. Most importantly, though, it’s a novel about marriage and companionship, about the afterworlds (or parallel worlds?) where our relationships continue – or perhaps, as Jake intuits, about the possibility of inhabiting “the place where the laws of physics and the laws of dreams mix.” In chilling but tender ways it’s a novel that teaches us that time is a gift, and that even if you’re aware that “you are nothing on the enormous mountain,” you must relish “living on the gradient” and must carve your turns with focus and joy. I knew little about this novel when I picked it up, which is unusual for me, but which probably helped turn it into one of the most memorable and searing reading experiences I've had in some time. I knew, I think, that it had won some manner of prize (in fact, it was the National Book Award!), but that was about it. I had no idea it was a Hurricane Katrina novel, or, certainly, that I would finish the novel and feel convinced that there will never be a Hurricane Katrina novel as good as this one (or many American novels of any kind as good as this one). That Jesmyn Ward is an amazing young talent is evidenced not just by the overall harrowing power of Salvage the Bones, but by the unforgettable (and utterly believable) powers of observation (amidst the almost tragic dereliction of life in what her family knows as "the Pit") of her narrator, Esch. The loss of the family's mother (after giving birth to Esch's brother, Junior) hovers around the sad, scrappy, and hardscrabble scenes of this narrative, and there's no small amount of discomfort for the reader to endure, whether it's weathering the tempests of Esch's father, the grit-your-teeth (literally) edginess of the dog-fighting drama, or, when it finally comes, the soggy, deafening, terrifying -- and, finally, heart-rending ("China White, he breathes, my China") -- punishment delivered by Katrina. The deep emotions and the pathos are assiduously earned, and when the storm passes and the sky clears, the endurance and hopefulness are, in the way of great fiction, both richly felt and soberingly modest. And through it all is that poetry, and a gathering of acutely realized, cutting details: we get astonishing renderings of the impoverished, rural South, "through miles of woods, lonely houses like possums in the dark, half caught and then left behind by the headlights"; a father's injured hand "wrapped up to the wrist in gauze and tape so that it looked like a webworm moth nest wound tight in a pecan tree"; a color-based cartography that finds Esch and her family living "in the black heart of Bois Sauvage" and their advantaged neighbors living "in the pale arteries."
